title: 103_hr1317
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Franchise Data and Public Information Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings section. The Congress finds that franchise business relationships are a significant and growing part of the American economy, replacing traditional small business ownership. However, there is a lack of reliable data on the number and operation of franchise businesses, as well as investigations into franchise failures. Despite the importance of franchising in the American marketplace, there is a lack of reliable statistical information on the number, ownership, and operation of franchise businesses. Objective data on franchise failures is also scarce. Promotional material often portrays franchises as uniformly successful and low-risk. Despite the lack of reliable statistics on franchise businesses, there is a large amount of misleading information in promotional material that portrays franchises as highly successful and low-risk. This inaccurate data is often attributed to Federal Government agencies and reports, with outdated information from the United States Department of Commerce being widely misused. Franchisees may face significant financial losses due to inaccurate or misleading statistical information about franchise businesses, often sourced from outdated data from the United States Department of Commerce. Franchisees may suffer substantial losses from inaccurate or misleading statistical information regarding franchise businesses. The purpose of this Act is to provide comprehensive statistical information about franchising to enhance reliability and assure prospective investors have necessary information. The Act aims to provide the public with comprehensive statistical information about franchising and franchise systems to ensure reliable information for prospective investors. The Act aims to provide the public with comprehensive statistical information about franchising and franchise systems to ensure reliable information for prospective investors. SEC. 3. NATIONAL FILING AND DATA COLLECTION. All individuals or entities selling franchises must file a copy of the franchise disclosure document with the Commerce Department. The document filed should be the most recent version. Franchise sellers must file the franchise disclosure document with the Commerce Department, which should be the most recent version incorporating current information. Franchise sellers must file the most recent version of the franchise disclosure document with the Commerce Department, which includes current information and the most restrictive version of the franchise agreement provided to prospective franchisees. The franchise disclosure document must be filed annually with the Commerce Department, including requirements and limitations in the franchise agreement. The Commerce Department will share these documents with Congress, the FTC, and other federal agencies upon request. The Commerce Department is responsible for sharing franchise disclosure documents with Congress, the FTC, and other federal agencies upon request. It is prohibited for franchisors to make false statements in connection with any advertisement or disclosure document. It is illegal for franchisors to falsely claim that a disclosure document has been reviewed by the Commerce Department or any other Federal agency. Franchisors cannot falsely claim that the Commerce Department or any other Federal agency has reviewed or approved their disclosure document. The Commerce Department must establish procedures for data collection and publication within 240 days of this section's enactment. The Commerce Department will establish procedures for compiling statistical information on franchise ownership and practices within 240 days of the enactment of this section. The principal source of data will be disclosure documents for franchise opportunities. The Commerce Department will establish procedures for compiling statistical information on franchise ownership and practices using disclosure documents for franchise opportunities. Categories of statistical information will be established for annual data compilation and analysis. The Commerce Department will establish categories of statistical information for annual data compilation on franchise ownership, including total numbers of franchisors, types of franchise businesses, growth rates, turnover, and franchise failures. They will consult with relevant entities for input. The Commerce Department will establish categories of statistical information for annual data compilation on franchise ownership, including growth rates, turnover, and franchise failures. They will consult with relevant entities for input on additional categories of statistical information. The Commerce Department will work with relevant organizations to identify additional categories of statistical information for data compilation and analysis, focusing on issues of public interest and regulatory concern. This information will be obtained from disclosure materials and other public sources. The Commerce Department will gather statistical information from disclosure materials and public sources, including periodic questionnaires to franchisors and franchisees. The Commerce Department will collect statistical information through periodic questionnaires of franchisors and franchisees to supplement data in disclosure documents. The Commerce Department will publish a report on statistical information collected through questionnaires from franchisors and franchisees, to supplement data in disclosure documents. The Commerce Department will publish a report on franchise ownership and national franchising practices, based on data collected from questionnaires and the Business Census. The report will be released annually to Congress and the public. SEC. 4. CENSUS DATA ON FRANCHISE BUSINESSES. The Bureau of the Census will include statistical information on franchise businesses in its Business Census for 1997 and future censuses. They will consult with the Federal Trade Commission to identify franchise businesses and establish categories of statistical information to be collected. The Bureau of Census will identify franchise businesses for inclusion in the Business Census and consult with Congress, the Federal Trade Commission, and other organizations to establish categories of statistical information to be collected. A report on cost-effective data gathering methods will be submitted to Congress within 280 days. The Bureau of Census will submit a report to Congress within 280 days, detailing cost-effective methods to collect statistical information on franchise businesses for the Business Census. SEC. 5. RULES, REGULATIONS AND FEES. The Secretary of Commerce is authorized to make rules and regulations to implement the Act, including classifications, adjustments, and exceptions deemed necessary. Additionally, the Secretary can collect a filing fee. The Secretary of Commerce can make rules and regulations, including adjustments and exceptions, to implement the Act. They are also authorized to collect a filing fee from those subject to the filing requirement to cover costs incurred by the Commerce Department. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines "advertisement" as a communication related to the offer or sale of a franchise, and "disclosure document" as a statement required by the Commission or an offering circular prepared according to guidelines. The term "franchise" refers to a continuing commercial relationship created by a contract where a franchisor grants the right to a franchisee. The term "franchise" means a continuing commercial relationship created by a contract where a franchisor grants the right to a franchisee to engage in the business of offering goods or services. The term "franchise" refers to a commercial relationship where a franchisor grants the right to a franchisee to offer goods or services associated with the franchisor's trademark or conform to quality standards. The franchisee must conform to quality standards established by the franchisor for the goods or services to be offered, sold, or distributed, and operate under a name that includes the franchisor's trademark. The franchisee must adhere to quality standards set by the franchisor for the goods or services and operate under a name that includes the franchisor's trademark. The franchisor also imparts knowledge, expertise, and trade secrets to the franchisee. The franchisor imparts knowledge, expertise, and trade secrets to the franchisee, regardless of whether it is proprietary or confidential, and provides significant assistance in the franchisee's method of operation. The franchisor imparts knowledge, expertise, and trade secrets to the franchisee, provides significant assistance in the franchisee's method of operation, and exercises significant controls over the franchisee's method of operation of the business. The franchisee must comply with these conditions to start or operate the business. The franchisor imparts knowledge, expertise, and trade secrets to the franchisee, provides significant assistance, and exercises controls over the franchisee's business operation. The franchisee is required to make payment or other consideration to the franchisor for goods for resale. The term "franchisee" refers to a person who is required to make payment or other consideration to the franchisor for goods for resale, a subfranchise, or any commercial relationship based on representations that certain criteria will be met. The term "franchisee" refers to a person granted a franchise, while a "franchisor" is the entity granting the franchise or subfranchise. A "person" can be a natural person or legal entity, and a "subfranchise" is a contract or agreement.
